Universal Spectral Correlations in the Chaotic Wave Function, and the Development of Quantum Chaos

Xiao Chen xchen@kitp.ucsb.edu Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics, University of California at Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA    Andreas W.W. Ludwig Department of Physics, University of California at Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA
Abstract

We investigate the appearance of quantum chaos in a single many-body wave function by analyzing the statistical properties of the eigenvalues of its reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of a spatial subsystem A𝐴A. We find that (i): the spectrum of the density matrix is described by so-called Wishart random matrix theory, which (ii): exhibits besides level repulsion, spectral rigidity and universal spectral correlations between eigenvalues separated by distances ranging from one up to many mean level spacings, which we investigate. We use these universal spectral characteristics of the reduced density matrix as a definition of chaos in the wave function. A simple and precise characterization of such universal correlations in a spectrum is a segment of strictly linear growth at sufficiently long times, recently called the “ramp”, of the spectral form factor which is the Fourier transform of the correlation function between a pair of eigenvalues. It turns out that Wishart and standard random matrix theory have the same universal “ramp”. Specifically, here numerical results for the spectral form factor of the density matrix of generic non-integrable many-body systems, such as one-dimensional quantum Ising and Floquet spin models, are found to exhibit an universal “ramp” identical to that appearing for a “random pure state” (“Page state”, or “Haar state”). The density matrix of the latter is precisely the Wishart random matrix, the reduced density matrix of a completely random wave function. In addition, we study the development of chaos in the wave function by letting an initial direct product state evolve under the unitary time evolution. We find that the universal spectral correlations as manifested by the “ramp” set in as soon as the entanglement entropy begins to grow, and first develop for the eigenvalues at the top of the spectrum of the density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}, subsequently spreading over the entire spectrum at later times. Finally, we study a prethermalized regime described by a generalized Gibbs ensemble, which develops in a rapidly driven Floquet model at intermediate times. We find that the prethermalized regime exhibits no chaos, as evidenced by the absence of a “ramp” in the spectral form factor of the density matrix, while the universal spectral correlations start to develop when the prethermalized regime finally relaxes at late times to the fully thermalized (infinite temperature) chaotic regime.

I Introduction

The characterization of chaos in quantum mechanical systems has a long history, and chaos plays a key role in the process of thermalization, i.e. relaxation to equilibrium in generic isolated many-body quantum systemsSrednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991). (See e.g. Ref.s Haake, 2013, Stoeckmann, 1999, T. Guhr, 1998, D’Alessio and Rigol, 2014 for a review.) It also plays an important role for the quantum nature of black holes.Shenker and Stanford (2014a, b, 2015); Maldacena et al. (2016); Kitaev (2014); Cotler et al. (2016) An important milestone in the study of quantum chaos has been the so-called Bohigas, Giannoni and Schmidt conjectureO. Bohigas (1984), which states that chaos manifests itself in the spectral properties of the Hamiltonian of a quantum system by exhibiting universal features which are the same as those of the spectrum of a random Hamiltonian matrix in the same symmetry class. Such universal features include, besides level repulsion statistics between adjacent spectral levels, spectral rigidity and more generally the correlation function between two levels which is universal for levels separated by energy scales that range from the mean level spacing to energy differences which can be much larger, up to scales at which model-dependent (“ultraviolet”) features set in. The corresponding universality classes are solely determined by the action of the anti-unitary time-reversal operator, giving rise to the three possible symmetry classes of spectral statistics depending on whether time reversal symmetry is absent (“GUE”, Dyson index β=2𝛽2\beta=2), or is present and squares to the identiy operator (“GOE”, Dyson index β=1𝛽1\beta=1) or squares to minus the identity operator (“GSE”, Dyson index β=4𝛽4\beta=4).

Spectral characteristics of a discrete spectrum of levels Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} are conveniently described by the so-called spectral form factor 111See e.g. Ref.s T. Guhr, 1998, Cotler et al., 2016, which is the Fourier transform of the correlation function between two levels, and can be written in the form

g​(τ)≡⟨∑i,je−i​τ​(Ei−Ej)⟩,(𝑆𝑝𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑙​𝐹𝑜𝑟𝑚​𝐹𝑎𝑐𝑡𝑜𝑟).𝑔𝜏delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑖𝑗superscript𝑒𝑖𝜏subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐸𝑗𝑆𝑝𝑒𝑐𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑙𝐹𝑜𝑟𝑚𝐹𝑎𝑐𝑡𝑜𝑟\displaystyle g(\tau)\equiv\langle\sum_{i,j}e^{-i\tau(E_{i}-E_{j})}\rangle,\qquad\qquad{\rm({\it Spectral\ Form\ Factor})}. (1)

Here τ𝜏\tau denotes an auxiliary real time (not to be confused with an ‘Euclidean’ or ‘imaginary’ time coordinate, often denoted by the same symbol), and ⟨…⟩delimited-⟨⟩…\langle...\rangle stands for a certain average, to be described in detail below, whose sole purpose is to remove non-universal rapid temporal fluctuations (in τ𝜏\tau) from the signal which originate from (non-universal) high frequency components corresponding to large energy differences (Ei−Ej)subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐸𝑗(E_{i}-E_{j}). In random matrix theory, considering here the simplest case where time-reversal symmetry is absent (“GUE-type” statistics), a simple and precise characterization of universal spectral correlations is a segment of strictly linear growth222For the other two symmetry classes the detailed shape of this growth segment has similar features, but the details are slightly different in time τ𝜏\tau, recently calledCotler et al. (2016) the “ramp”, of the spectral form factor g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) at sufficiently long times up to the so-called Heisenberg time τHsubscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{H} (defined to be 2​π2𝜋2\pi times the inverse of the mean level spacing), where it suddenly becomes completely flat, reaching its long-time “plateau” value, as sketched333The plotted data are actually for the reduced density matrix of a typical one-dimensional Floquet many-body system to be discussed in Section II.3.1 and in Fig. 3 of the main text, but this is not relevant for the current discussion. in Fig. 1. [The Heisenberg time has also been called “plateau time” τp≡τHsubscript𝜏𝑝subscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{p}\equiv\tau_{H}.] More precisely, the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) obtained444See detailed discussions below (6), (7), (8). from (1) by subtracting a (non-universal) disconnected piece |⟨∑ie−i​τ​Ei⟩|2superscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑖superscript𝑒𝑖𝜏subscript𝐸𝑖2|\langle\sum_{i}e^{-i\tau E_{i}}\rangle|^{2}, turns out to exhibit a longer segment of universal, strictly linear growth (“ramp”) for time scales τ𝜏\tau larger than a shortest time scale τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} below which (in applications, e.g. to spectra of Hamiltonians describing quantum chaos) possible non-universal features set in. I.e., the region τ≲τ0less-than-or-similar-to𝜏subscript𝜏0\tau\lesssim\tau_{0} corresponds to differences of energies (Ei−Ej)subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐸𝑗(E_{i}-E_{j}) which exceed the universal regime. - In the (non-connected) spectral form factor g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) from (1), a portion of this universal segment of linear growth in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) turns out to be hidden at small times larger than τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} by possible non-universal features of the disconnected part, and g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) typically only exhibits a shorter part of the entire universal linear “ramp”, as depicted in Fig. 1.

It was shownBerry (1985); Hannay and Ozorio De Almeida (1984) many years ago that in chaotic quantum systems with a small number of degrees of freedom whose classical limit is ergodic, the “ramp” for the energy spectrum of the Hamiltonian can be computed analytically in the semiclassical limit by making use of Gutzwiller’s Trace FormulaGutzwiller (1990) and known properties of asymptotically long classical periodic orbits. In these cases, the time-scale τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} characterizes the onset of potential non-universal contributions to gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) for τ≲τ0less-than-or-similar-to𝜏subscript𝜏0\tau\lesssim\tau_{0} arising from short orbits. On the other hand, the spectral form factor has very recently formed a topic of extensive discussion in the context of the Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model Sachdev and Ye (1993); Kitaev (2015); Maldacena and Stanford (2016), a strongly chaotic quantum system, whose Hamiltonian has been shown numerically to exhibit a spectrum possessing the expected “ramp”. A recent lucid discussion of many aspects of the spectral form factor, with an emphasis on the Hamiltonian spectrum of the SYK model, can be found in Ref. Cotler et al., 2016. - In contrast, these universal spectral correlations are absent in an integrable system, where the spectral form factor exhibits no “ramp” (and the probability distribution for the spacing between adjacent levels is Poissonian).

In the present paper, we are going to show that the universal spectral correlations manifested by a strictly linear “ramp” already appear at the level of a single many-body wavefunction of a generic chaotic quantum system, without focusing attention on the spectrum of the Hamiltonian of the system; we also discuss periodically driven Floquet systems.

For thermalizing (chaotic) systems whose time-evolution is governed by a time-independent Hamiltonian (i.e. not Floquet systems), our work can be motivated by the connection between a typical state and the thermal ensemble, a notion inherent in the eigenstate thermalization hypothesisSrednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991) (ETH), which we now briefly summarize as follows: Let |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle be a state at finite energy density e=E/V𝑒𝐸𝑉e=E/V (i.e. ⟨ψ|H^|ψ⟩=quantum-operator-product𝜓^𝐻𝜓absent\langle\psi|{\hat{H}}|\psi\rangle= E=𝐸absentE= e​V𝑒𝑉e\ V, where V𝑉V is the volume), which can either be a highly excited exact eigenstate of a chaotic Hamiltonian H^^𝐻{\hat{H}} in the spatial volume V𝑉V, or just a typical short-range entangled initial state (which is not an eigenstate of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}) acted on by the corresponding unitary quantum mechanical time-evolution operator for a sufficiently long time. ETH states that the expectation value of a product of local operators in the state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle equals the thermal expectation value of this product at a temperature determined by e𝑒e in the usual sense of microcanonical Statistical Mechanics. For Floquet systems, these expectations values in the analogous state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle are at infinite temperature.

Here we consider the reduced density matrix in a spatial subregion A𝐴A (B𝐵B =A¯absent¯𝐴={\bar{A}} is the complement of A𝐴A) of such a typical state,

ρ^A=TrB​|ψ⟩​⟨ψ|.subscript^𝜌𝐴subscriptTr𝐵ket𝜓bra𝜓\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}=\mbox{Tr}_{B}\ |\psi\rangle\langle\psi|. (2)

We will show that the spectral form factor for the spectrum of eigenvalues λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A},

g​(τ)≡⟨∑i,je−i​τ​(λi−λj)⟩,𝑔𝜏delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑖𝑗superscript𝑒𝑖𝜏subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑗\displaystyle g(\tau)\equiv\langle\sum_{i,j}e^{-i\tau(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{j})}\rangle, (3)

exhibits a “ramp”. As mentioned above, the presence of a “ramp” in the spectral form factor demonstrates the presence of universal spectral correlations over a possibly large range of scales (determined by τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} and τHsubscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{H}) in the spectrum of eigenvalues of the density matrix. Thus, in this paper we use the presence of these universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix of a typical quantum state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle, as manifested by the presence of a “ramp” in the associated spectral form factor, to define the notion of quantum chaos in the state (i.e. “in the wavefunction”). In particular, we will show at the technical level that spectral properties of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} are described by so-called Wishart random matrix theoryForrester (2010). As it turns out, Wishart random matrix theory exhibits universal spectral correlations idential to those appearing in standard (here555since we consider systems without time-reversal symmetry GUE) random matrix theory; in particular they have the same universal linear “ramp” (see Sect. IV.3 and Appendix B).

For systems whose time-evolution is governed by a time-independent Hamiltonian, we can look at this also from a slightly different angle: Instead of investigating the spectral statistics of the reduced density matrix, one may also be inclined to consider the spectral statistics of the associated entanglement Hamiltonian H^Esubscript^𝐻𝐸{\hat{H}}_{E} defined by

ρ^A=𝒩E−1​exp⁡{−βe​f​f​H^E}.subscript^𝜌𝐴superscriptsubscript𝒩𝐸1subscript𝛽𝑒𝑓𝑓subscript^𝐻𝐸\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}={\cal N}_{E}^{-1}\exp\{-\beta_{eff}{\hat{H}}_{E}\}. (4)

The spectral form factor for the entanglement Hamiltonian is obtained from (3) by letting λi→→subscript𝜆𝑖absent\lambda_{i}\to −ln⁡λisubscript𝜆𝑖-\ln\lambda_{i}. As discussed in Appendix A, the two spectral form factors, of ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}_{A}} and of H^Esubscript^𝐻𝐸{\hat{H}}_{E}, exhibit identical universal features in their respective level statistics. In particular, in a chaotic system they both exhibit a linear “ramp”. Now, one may think of the entanglement Hamiltonian and of (4) in the light of a strong version of ETH proposed in Ref. Garrison and Grover, 2015, which states that the reduced density matrix of the single state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle takes on a thermal form, ρ^A=subscript^𝜌𝐴absent{\hat{\rho}}_{A}= 𝒩A−1​exp⁡{−β​H^A}superscriptsubscript𝒩𝐴1𝛽subscript^𝐻𝐴{\cal N}_{A}^{-1}\exp\{-\beta{\hat{H}}_{A}\}, where H^Asubscript^𝐻𝐴{\hat{H}}_{A} is the physical (chaotic) Hamiltonian of the system, projected onto the region of subsystem A𝐴A. Note that this strong version of ETHGarrison and Grover (2015) is a quite non-trivial statement because even though ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} is constructed from a single state [see (2)], this statement implies that ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} contains the knowledge of the entire Hamiltonian of the system, or rather at least of its projection onto A𝐴A. - Then, if one assumes the validity of the above-mentioned strong version of ETH, one would naturally expect that the universal correlations in the spectrum of the entanglement Hamiltonian H^Esubscript^𝐻𝐸{\hat{H}}_{E} are directly inherited from those of the physical Hamiltonian H^Asubscript^𝐻𝐴{\hat{H}}_{A} (which, according to the Bohigas, Giannoni and Schmidt conjecture, is expected to exhibit universal spectral correlations). Thus, since we observe (as mentioned) that ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} and H^Esubscript^𝐻𝐸{\hat{H}}_{E} exhibit the same universal features in their spectral form factors, it would be natural to expect the appearance the universal spectral correlations (and the “ramp”) in the entanglement Hamiltonian of a single state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle. Put another way, for thermalizing (chaotic) systems whose time-evolution is governed by a time-independent Hamiltonian, our results can thus also be viewed as a confirmation of the strong version of ETH proposed in Ref. Garrison and Grover, 2015.

In order to investigate explicitly the presence of the mentioned universal correlations in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix (2) in many-body quantum chaos, we numerically compute the spectral form factor of the density matrix of a typical single many-body wave function |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle [as defined in the paragraph above (2)], in two generic non-integrable one-dimensional systems: a Floquet spin model, and a quantum Ising model in both transverse and logitudinal field. As will be shown below in the bulk of the paper, we clearly observe for both systems a linear “ramp” in the spectral form factors of their density matrices, confirming the corresponding universal spectral correlations in their spectra of eigenvalues. Furthermore, in order to provide a generic, model-independent description of the universal features of quantum chaos in a wave function, we consider a so-called “random pure state”, or “Page state” (“Haar state”)Page (1993),

|Ψ​({αi})⟩=∑iαi​|Ci⟩,ketΨsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖ketsubscript𝐶𝑖\displaystyle|\Psi(\{\alpha_{i}\})\rangle=\sum_{i}\alpha_{i}\ |C_{i}\rangle, (5)

in which the coefficients αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} of the state in a fixed basis {|Ci⟩}isubscriptketsubscript𝐶𝑖𝑖\{|C_{i}\rangle\}_{i} are random complex numbers subject solely to the normalization constraint, with a probability distribution invariant under unitary basis changes. The set of coefficients {αi}isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑖\{\alpha_{i}\}_{i} can thus be considered a row (or column) vector of a unitary random matrix (distributed according to the Haar measure). When we now form the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the “random pure state” (5) in a spatial region A𝐴A, we obtain a random matrix which turns out to belong to the well-studied “Wishart random matrix ensemble” (see Sect. IV.1 below for a more detailed discussion). The probability distribution for the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix and hence of the density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the “random pure state” are known analytically (as reviewed in Sect. IV.2), and the spectral form factor for ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} can be shown analytically (see Subsection IV.3 and Appendix B) to exhibit a linear “ramp” in the limit of large density matrices, reflecting the presence of universal spectral correlations in their spectra. As already mentioned, the linear “ramp” in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) for the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix turns out to be identical to that of standard random matrix theory in the same symmetry class (see Sect. IV.3 and Appendix B). The spectral form factor for the “random pure state” is discussed in detail in Sect. II.2 below. In Sect. II.3 we compare the numerically obtained spectral form factors of the Floquet and the quantum Ising systems with that of the “random pure state” (for the same system sizes) and find full agreement of the universal features. This means that Wishart random matrix theory describes the spectral correlations of the reduced density matrix of a single many-body wave function in typical chaotic systems of Hamiltonian and Floquet type in their universal regime, just as ordinary random matrix theory is thought to describe the level statistics of a chaotic Hamiltonian (according to the Bohigas, Giannoni and Schmidt conjectureO. Bohigas (1984).) The Floquet and quantum Ising systems considered in this paper lack time-reversal symmetry and so the “GUE” Wishart random matrix ensemble will be appropriate.

Subsequently, we explore the important question of development of quantum chaos under quantum mechanical unitary time evolution. Recently, it has been proposed that the “out-of-time-ordered” correlation function (OTOC) can probe the development of chaotic dynamics and scrambling of quantum information.Larkin and Ovchinnikov (1969); Shenker and Stanford (2014a, b, 2015); Maldacena et al. (2016); Kitaev (2014) At early times, the OTOC can exhibit an exponentially growing regime, the growth rate of which represents a quantum analog of the (classical) Lyapunov exponent. In this paper, we will study instead as an indicator of the development of quantum chaos the emergence of universal spectral correlations and of the corresponding “ramp” in the spectral form factor, in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) as a function of time t𝑡t in a quantum quench problem. ETH states that an (sufficiently general short-range entangled) initial state which is not an eigenstate, relaxes under the quantum mechanical time evolution, after a sufficiently long time, to a state which appears to be (in the sense of ETH, as reviewed above) in thermal equilibrium (at infinite temperature for Floquet systems).Srednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991) Therefore, if we start with an initial direct product state, one expects that while the spectrum of the reduced density matrix ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) will initially exhibit no spectral correlations, under the unitary time evolution a “ramp” will emerge after a sufficiently long time t𝑡t in its spectral form factor. We consider both (one-dimensional) Floquet and quantum Ising models and find that a “ramp” starts to develop as soon as the entanglement entropy begins to grow. More precisely, it is interesting to note that universal spectral correlations are first seen to appear for the eigenvalues at the top of the spectrum of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t), and subsequently spread out over the entire spectrum at later times.

We emphasize that there is no direct connection between the appearance of a volume law in the entanglement entropy and quantum chaos. In integrable systems, initial direct product states (as above) are typically expected to thermalize to a generalized Gibbs ensemble (GGE) after sufficiently long unitary time evolutionRigol et al. (2007, 2006); Calabrese and Cardy (2007); Cardy (2015). Although the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} for these GGE states possesses an entanglement entropy exhibiting a volume law, the eigenvalues of this density matrix are not expected to exhibit the discussed universal spectral correlations, in contrast to the reduced density matrix of chaotic (thermalizing) systems discussed above. To illustrate this point explicitly, we have constructed a rapidly driven Floquet system whose time evolution, starting out from a direct product state, exhibits a long, stable so-called prethermalized regimeMori et al. (2016); Abanin et al. (2015, 2017); Else et al. (2017) at intermediate times. This prethermalized regime, accompanied by a long plateau in the time-dependence of the entanglement entropy exhibiting a volume law, will be seen to be clearly devoid of chaos as evidenced from the absence of the characterisic universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of the density matrix ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t), which is manifested by the absence of a “ramp” in the corresponding spectral form factor. A linear “ramp” in the spectral form factor is seen to develop only when the prethermalized regime eventually relaxes at very late times to the fully thermalized chaotic regime, in which the conservation laws (approximately) present in the prethermalized regime cease to exist.

We end the introduction by mentioning some related work. Level repulsion statistics between adjacent levels of the density matrix of thermalizing systems with a main focus on disordered systems has been discussed in the context of work investigating Many-Body-Localization (MBL) in Ref. Yang et al., 2017 and Geraedts et al., 2016. Our work, in contrast, discusses spectral rigidity and, in particular, the universal spectral correlations and the “ramp” in the spectral form factor, focusing on non-random chaotic systems, and it elucidates the origins of these spectral correlations in the “random pure state” (Page state) and in Wishart random matrix theory, both for Hamiltonian and Floquet systems. Furthermore, we identify the development of chaos as the process of buildup of these spectral correlations in the density matrix under the unitary time-evolution. We also discuss a prethermal regime, lacking chaos, and its late-time relaxation to a chaotic state.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Sect. II, we first discuss the spectral form factor in the “random pure state” (Page state) and its linear “ramp”. Then, we discuss the spectral form factors of typical wavefunctions of non-integrable Floquet and quantum Ising models for the same system sizes, and show that they both exhibit the same universal linear “ramp” as the “random pure state”. In Sect. III, we discuss the development of chaos in these Floquet and Ising model wavefunctions by computing the time evolution of the spectral form factor. Moreover, we explore the development of chaos in a Floquet model which exhibits a long prethermal regime at intermediate times. In Sect. IV, we compute the spectral form factor in “random pure state” (Page state) analytically by using some basic knowledge of the Wishart ensemble and compare the result with the numerical calculations in Sect. II. We summarize and conclude in Sect. V.

II Spectral Form Factor

II.1 General Discussion

We decompose the Hilbert space of the total system of dimension N𝑁N (of which the “typical” state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle is an element) into a tensor product of the Hilbert spaces of the two subsystems, system A𝐴A with Hilbert space dimension NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}, and system B𝐵B with Hilbert space dimension NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} (i.e. N=NA​NB𝑁subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N=N_{A}N_{B}). The spectral form factor g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) for the NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} eigenvalues λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} defined in (3) above, can be conveniently expressed666In the present paper we often follow the notations used in Ref. Cotler et al., 2016. in terms of the Fourier transform of the eigenvalue density

Z​(τ)≡Tr​exp⁡(−i​τ​ρ^A)=∑i=1NAexp⁡(−i​τ​λi)𝑍𝜏Tr𝑖𝜏subscript^𝜌𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝐴𝑖𝜏subscript𝜆𝑖\displaystyle Z(\tau)\equiv\mbox{Tr}\ \exp(-i\tau{\hat{\rho}}_{A})=\sum_{i=1}^{N_{A}}\exp(-i\tau\lambda_{i}) (6)

as follows

g​(τ)=⟨∑i,j=1NAe−i​τ​(λi−λj)⟩=⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩.𝑔𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1subscript𝑁𝐴superscript𝑒𝑖𝜏subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑗delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\displaystyle g(\tau)=\langle\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{A}}e^{-i\tau(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{j})}\rangle=\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle. (7)

As seen from (7), at τ=0𝜏0\tau=0 the spectral form factor clearly takes on the value g​(τ=0)=(NA)2𝑔𝜏0superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐴2g(\tau=0)=(N_{A})^{2}, while in the limit τ→∞→𝜏\tau\to\infty only contributions with λi=λjsubscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑗\lambda_{i}=\lambda_{j} survive, which yields the smaller value limτ→∞g​(τ)=subscript→𝜏𝑔𝜏absent\lim_{\tau\to\infty}g(\tau)= NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}. As we will see below, the function g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) initially decreases starting from τ=0𝜏0\tau=0 until it reaches a minimum (“dip”), then exhibits a segment of linear rise (“ramp”), until the curve suddenly becomes constant (at the Heisenberg time τHsubscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{H}) reaching its late-time “plateau” value [see e.g. Fig. 1]. As we will review below, the initial decrease at early times is non-universal, whereas the linear “ramp” is completely universal, depending only on the symmetry class. We note that the presence of these three distinct regimes, the decrease until the “dip”, the linear rise along the “ramp”, and the flat plateau, was stressed in the context of the spectral form factor of the Hamiltonian of the SYK model in the recent Ref. Cotler et al., 2016 already mentioned above.

We will also consider the connected spectral form factor

gc​(τ)=⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩−⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩,subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\displaystyle g_{c}(\tau)=\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle-\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\ \langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle, (8)

which exhibits (as already mentioned) a longer and more pronounced “ramp” [compare e.g. Fig. 1]. Its analytic form for the “random pure state” and the Wishart random matrix ensemble is displayed in (41) of Sect. IV in the limit of a large density matrix. In the context of the spectrum of a random (GUE, GOE or GSE) Hamiltonian matrix, the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) has been extensively discussed in the literature over many years.777See e.g. Ref. T. Guhr, 1998 for an extensive review.

As already mentioned in the Introduction (Sect. I), the purpose of the average ⟨…⟩delimited-⟨⟩…\langle...\rangle in (7) and (8) is to remove non-universal rapid temporal fluctuationsPrange (1997) from the spectral form factor g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau). In our work reported below, there will be a natural ensemble available over which to perform the average as an ensemble average: For the “random pure state” (Page state) discussed in Sect. II.2 below, this will be an average over the statistical ensemble of “random pure states”, while for the Floquet and quantum Ising models in Sect. II.3 this will be an ensemble of initial direct product states. Another way to remove the high-frequency fluctuations from the spectral form factor g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) is to coarse grain the latter in time τ𝜏\tau by convolution with a temporal “smearing function” which eliminates high frequencies components from the signal. (For example, see Refs. Cotler et al., 2016; Balasubramanian et al., 2017.) Since the ensemble averages were more convenient for us, we did not use the coarse graining approach in the present work to remove the high frequency fluctuations.

II.2 Random pure state

Since, as already mentioned in the Introduction, this will turn out to provide a model-independent description of the universal properties of quantum chaos in a wave function, we first study the spectral form factor of the “random pure state” (Page state), discussed in (5) and the paragraph below that equation. The reduced density matrix for a “random pure state” is also a random matrix and it turns out to belong to the so-called (unitary) Wishart ensemble with Dyson index β=2𝛽2\beta=2, in which the spectral density satisfies the so-called Marchenko-Pastur distribution.Forrester (2010) (See Sect. IV for a review.)

Using this property, Page showedPage (1993) that the ensemble-averaged (von Neumann) entanglement entropy [EE] of the reduced density matrix for subsystem A of the “random pure state” is equal to

⟨SA⟩=log⁡NA−NA2​NB.delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑆𝐴subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐴2subscript𝑁𝐵\displaystyle\langle S_{A}\rangle=\log N_{A}-\frac{N_{A}}{2N_{B}}. (9)

(Recall that NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} and NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} are Hilbert space dimensions for subsystem A and its complement B, respectively, and we have assumed NA≤NBsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N_{A}\leq N_{B} without loss of generality.)

Since the Hilbert space dimension NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} grows exponentionally with the volume of subsystem A𝐴A, the entanglement entropy of the random product state exhibits according to (9) a volume law (as expected). For example, for the Ising-type systems considered in the present paper which have a local (onsite) Hilbert space dimension of two, we have NA=2LAsubscript𝑁𝐴superscript2subscript𝐿𝐴N_{A}=2^{L_{A}} where LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A} is the number of lattice sites of subsystem A𝐴A. We thus seen from (9) that the entanglement entropy of the “random pure state” exhibits a volume law of maximal possible value (given the dimension of the onsite Hilbert space), up to a small subleading term which depends on the ratio of the Hilbert space dimensions of subsystems A𝐴A and B𝐵B, which we denote by α≡NA/NB𝛼subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵\alpha\equiv N_{A}/N_{B}. The latter subleading term in (9) takes on its maximal value 1/2121/2 at α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, and approaches zero as NA≪NBmuch-less-thansubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N_{A}\ll N_{B}.

It it known analytically (as reviewed in Sect. IV below) that the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix exhibit the same universal spectral correlations as those of the Hamiltonian of the GUE random matrix ensemble, which manifest themselves, as already mentioned, in the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau). We have computed numerically the (non-connected) spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)=⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle for the eigenvalues of the Wishart random matrix, describing the reduced density matrix of the “random pure state”. The results are plotted in Fig. 2 which shows that when α=NA/NB<1𝛼subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵1\alpha=N_{A}/N_{B}<1, there is an intermediate linear “ramp” where g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle grows linearly with time τ𝜏\tau. The presence of the “ramp” demonstrates the presence of the mentioned universal spectral correlations, as discussed analytically in Sect. IV below (compare also Fig. 1).

Continuing with α=NA/NB<1𝛼subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵1\alpha=N_{A}/N_{B}<1, we also observe in Fig. 2 an early time regime where g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle drops down quickly to a minimum value. It turns out that at early times, ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle factorizes into ⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle and is therefore determined by the Fourier transform of the average of the eigenvalue density, ⟨Z​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle, defined in (6). One can determine from Fig. 2, where g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle is plotted versus τ𝜏\tau for NA=212subscript𝑁𝐴superscript212N_{A}=2^{12} (and N=226𝑁superscript226N=2^{26}, i.e. when α=1/4𝛼14\alpha=1/4), that it scales as 1/τ31superscript𝜏31/\tau^{3} in this early time regime. Moreover, we observe in the plots shown in the same figure for smaller values of α𝛼\alpha, that there are large oscillations in this early time regime888These oscillations can be systematically reduced by averaging over larger samples., but with an envelope function that is still close to 1/τ31superscript𝜏31/\tau^{3}, when compared to the α=1/4𝛼14\alpha=1/4 case.

This power law decay behavior of the spectral form factor at early times originates from the eigenvalue distribution function ⟨Z​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle of the Wishart matrix which will be analytically computed in Sect. IV.2. For a generic chaotic system with Hamiltonian H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}, the details of the eigenvalue distribution function of the density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} for a typical wavefunction will in general be different from that of the Wishart matrix, and will not be universal. In particular, in the early time regime where the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle factorizes into ⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle, it will be model-dependent, in contrast to the regime of intermediate τ𝜏\tau where it exhibits a universal “ramp”, whose presence depends solely on the universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of eigenvalues.

As already discussed, at late times τ𝜏\tau larger than the Heisenberg time τHsubscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{H}, the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z​(τ)∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏𝑍superscript𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z(\tau)^{*}\rangle will saturate to a constant value NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}, which is coming from the terms with λi=λjsubscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑗\lambda_{i}=\lambda_{j} [see (7)]. Since, as has also been mentioned, the saturation value is much smaller than the initial value NA2superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐴2N_{A}^{2} attained at τ=0𝜏0\tau=0 [see again (7)], we plot g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle on a log-log scale so that the behavior of ⟨Z​Z∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍superscript𝑍\langle ZZ^{*}\rangle at the different time scales τ𝜏\tau can be seen clearly. The three time-regimes mentioned in Sect. (II.1) are separated by two typical time scales: The time where the “dip” occurs (“dip time”) τdsubscript𝜏𝑑\tau_{d}, and the time where the plateau begins (“plateau time”, or “Heisenberg time”) τp=τHsubscript𝜏𝑝subscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{p}=\tau_{H}. We find that the dip time τdsubscript𝜏𝑑\tau_{d} scales as NA​Nsubscript𝑁𝐴𝑁\sqrt{N_{A}N}, while τpsubscript𝜏𝑝\tau_{p} is found to scale as NA​Nsubscript𝑁𝐴𝑁N_{A}\sqrt{N}. (Recall N=NA​NB𝑁subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N=N_{A}N_{B}.) [Both statements are obtained analytically in Sect. IV, and have also been checked numerically.] This is analogous to the three regimes observed in Ref. Cotler et al., 2016 for the spectral form factor for a M×M𝑀𝑀M\times M random matrix in the GUE ensemble (as compared to the Wishard random matrix ensemble discussed here), where τd∼Msimilar-tosubscript𝜏𝑑𝑀\tau_{d}\sim\sqrt{M} and τp∼Msimilar-tosubscript𝜏𝑝𝑀\tau_{p}\sim M.

We finally discuss a subtlety occuring when α=NA/NB=1𝛼subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵1\alpha=N_{A}/N_{B}=1. In contrast to the case where α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 discussed above, we see from Fig. 2 [top curve, NA=213subscript𝑁𝐴superscript213N_{A}=2^{13}, where the total Hilbert space dimension is N=226𝑁superscript226N=2^{26}] that for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 the intermediate “ramp” in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) disappears. The difference between α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 is caused by the different behavior of ⟨Z​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle: At early times, where g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩∼similar-todelimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏absent\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle\sim ⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle factorizes, for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 the spectral form factor scales as 1/τ1𝜏1/\tau and then directly transits to the plateau. However, the absence of the “ramp” does not mean that universal spectral correlations are absent in the spectrum of eigenvalues when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. Rather, the different behavior of ⟨Z​Z∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍superscript𝑍\langle ZZ^{*}\rangle just turns out to hide the “ramp” due to the slow decay of the disconnected part ⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle. The effect of the slowly decaying ⟨Z​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle can be removed if we consider instead the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)=subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏absentg_{c}(\tau)= ⟨Z​Z∗⟩−⟨Z⟩​⟨Z∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍superscript𝑍delimited-⟨⟩𝑍delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍\langle ZZ^{*}\rangle-\langle Z\rangle\langle Z^{*}\rangle, which is plotted in Fig. 2. In the latter figure we observe a long “ramp” even for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. Actually, for the other curves with α<1𝛼1\alpha<1 in the same figure, the linear “ramp” in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) starts at an earlier time (denoted earlier by τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0} - see Fig. 1) than the “ramp” in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau), where part of the longer linear “ramp” in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) is in fact covered up by ⟨Z⟩​⟨Z∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍\langle Z\rangle\langle Z^{*}\rangle as depicted in Fig. 2. Since small values of τ𝜏\tau correspond to large eigenvalue differences on the scale of the mean level spacing, the early-time part τ0≤τ≪τHsubscript𝜏0𝜏much-less-thansubscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{0}\leq\tau\ll\tau_{H} of the “ramp” in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) describes the spectral correlations of eigenvalues separated by an energy scale of many times the mean level spacing. Eventually, as τ𝜏\tau is close to τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0}, the universal behavior of gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) reflected in the linear “ramp” will be limited by model-dependent (“ultraviolet”) effects at large separations of eigenvalues, leading to deviations from the linear “ramp” at yet smaller values of τ≲τ0less-than-or-similar-to𝜏subscript𝜏0\tau\lesssim\tau_{0}.

The length of the “ramp” in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) increases with the number of eigenvalues that exhibit universal spectral correlations.Cotler et al. (2016) We clearly see from Fig. 2 that both the length of “ramp”, and the position of τpsubscript𝜏𝑝\tau_{p}, are linearly proportional (on a log scale) to log⁡NAsubscript𝑁𝐴\log N_{A}.

We finally want to mention that the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} studied in this section belongs to the Wishart random matrix ensemble lacking time-reversal symmetry, described by Dyson index β=2𝛽2\beta=2 (i.e. the “GUE-type” version of the Wishart random matrix ensemble). We can also consider a density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} described by a Wishart ensemble with Dyson index β=1,4𝛽14\beta=1,4 (the “GOE” and the “GSE” version of the Wishart random matrix ensemble), in which the details of the universal spectral correlations are slightly different. In the spectral form factor, these modified spectral correlations between the eigenvalues are reflected in a similar but slightly more complicated universal “ramp”.Forrester (2010) While a straightforward extension, we will not discuss details of these cases explicitly in this paper.

II.3 Floquet and Quantum Ising models

For a generic chaotic system with a time-independent Hamiltonian H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}, we expect that for the states |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle with energy expectation value E𝐸E (=⟨ψ|H^|ψ⟩=e​Vabsentquantum-operator-product𝜓^𝐻𝜓𝑒𝑉=\langle\psi|{\hat{H}}|\psi\rangle=eV, where e𝑒e is the energy density) in the middle of the spectrum of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}, the resulting density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the subsystem is well thermalized and its entanglement entropy exhibits a volume law. As already mentioned in the introduction, one might expect based on notions from ETH that the spectrum of this reduced density matrix exhibits universal spectral correlations. In this section, we will show more specifically for both, one-dimensional Floquet and quantum Ising models, that the spectra of the reduced density matrices of the above-mentioned states |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle have the same universal properties as those of the “random pure states” (Page states), and that the universal features of their reduced density matrix are in fact those of the Wishart random matrix, which is the reduced density matrix of the “random pure state”, the density matrix of a completely random wave function.

For practical reasons, instead of diagonalizing the Hamiltonian (or the Floquet operator) to investigate the spectral statistics the reduced density matix obtained for the subsystem for a typical eigenstatefoo , we will choose a set of initial product states |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0|\Psi_{0}\rangle (which thus are not entangled) and let them evolve under the unitary evolution governed by the Floquet operator or Ising Hamiltonian, i.e.,

|Ψ0​(t)⟩=U​(t)​|Ψ0⟩.ketsubscriptΨ0𝑡𝑈𝑡ketsubscriptΨ0\displaystyle|\Psi_{0}(t)\rangle=U(t)|\Psi_{0}\rangle. (10)

This is actually a quantum quench problem. For a generic non-integrable system, the initial wave function |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0|\Psi_{0}\rangle will eventually, at long times t𝑡t, thermalize under its own dynamics and the reduced density matrix ρ^A​(t)=TrB​|Ψ0​(t)⟩​⟨Ψ0​(t)|subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡subscriptTr𝐵ketsubscriptΨ0𝑡brasubscriptΨ0𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t)=\mbox{Tr}_{B}|\Psi_{0}(t)\rangle\langle\Psi_{0}(t)| will approach the reduced density matrix of a generic eigenstate of the Hamiltonian.Srednicki (1994); Deutsch (1991) Universal spectral correlations will develop in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix starting from such unentangled initial states, so that the final state obtained after sufficiently long time evolution will be fully thermalized. The advantage of this method is that we can work with relatively large systems (the time evolution operator simply has to be applied for a long time). Specifically, we will consider below one-dimensional Floquet and Ising models with L=20𝐿20L=20 lattice sites.

II.3.1 Floquet model

We first consider a Floquet model. It is known that Floquet systems can thermalize very rapidly due to the absence of any conservation laws.Kim et al. (2014); D’Alessio and Rigol (2014); Lazarides et al. (2014); Ponte et al. (2015); Zhang et al. (2015) The properties of such periodically driven systems are determined by the unitary time evolution operator over one period, i.e., the Floquet operator. Following Ref. Kim et al., 2014, we consider the following Floquet operator

U^F=exp⁡[−i​t0​H^z]​exp⁡[−i​t0​H^x],subscript^𝑈𝐹𝑖subscript𝑡0subscript^𝐻𝑧𝑖subscript𝑡0subscript^𝐻𝑥\displaystyle\hat{U}_{F}=\exp[-it_{0}\hat{H}_{z}]\exp\left[-it_{0}\hat{H}_{x}\right]~{}, (11)

where

H^x=∑j=1Lg​σ^jxsubscript^𝐻𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿𝑔superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗𝑥\displaystyle\hat{H}_{x}=\sum_{j=1}^{L}g\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{x}
H^z=∑j=1L−1σ^jz​σ^j+1z+∑j=1Lh​σ^jz,subscript^𝐻𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿1superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗𝑧superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗1𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿ℎsuperscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗𝑧\displaystyle\hat{H}_{z}=\sum_{j=1}^{L-1}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{z}\hat{\sigma}_{j+1}^{z}+\sum_{j=1}^{L}h\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{z}~{}, (12)

and σ^jxsubscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑥𝑗{\hat{\sigma}}^{x}_{j} and σ^jzsubscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑧𝑗{\hat{\sigma}}^{z}_{j} are standard Pauli matrices acting on lattice site j𝑗j. This model is a one-dimensional periodically driven system with period T=2​t0𝑇2subscript𝑡0T=2t_{0}. In the numerical calculations discussed below we choose open boundary conditions and typical system parameters (g,h,t0)=(0.9045,0.8090,0.8)𝑔ℎsubscript𝑡00.90450.80900.8(g,h,t_{0})=(0.9045,0.8090,0.8).

We choose a set of initial states which are random product states (hence unentangled, having vanishing EE) with the direction of the spin at each lattice site chosen independently from a uniform distribution on the Bloch sphere.

Since we are considering a Floquet model, the evolution time t𝑡t is an integer multiple of T𝑇T, i.e., t=n​T𝑡𝑛𝑇t=nT with n∈ℤ+𝑛subscriptℤn\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}. For the parameters we are considering here, it only takes a small number of time-steps to achieve thermalization. The details of the thermalization process itself and of the development of chaos will be discussed in Sect. III below. Here we discuss the properties of the fully thermalized state that the system takes on after sufficiently long time-evolution. Note that since for a Floquet system energy is not conserved, one expects that the subsystem (LA≤L/2subscript𝐿𝐴𝐿2L_{A}\leq L/2) will always thermalize to a state at infinite temperature close to the “random pure state” discussed above.Zhang et al. (2015)

In Fig. 3 we present numerical results for the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle and for the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)=subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏absentg_{c}(\tau)= [⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩−⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩]delimited-[]delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏[\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle-\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle] at time-step n=30𝑛30n=30, when the system is fully thermalized. We see from Fig. 3 that both, for LA=9subscript𝐿𝐴9L_{A}=9 and for LA=10subscript𝐿𝐴10L_{A}=10 [here L=20𝐿20L=20], both quantities g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) and gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) are indistinguishable from those for the “random pure state”. The “ramp” in g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle is absent when LA=10=L/2subscript𝐿𝐴10𝐿2L_{A}=10=L/2, but becomes visible once we subtract the disconnected part ⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle to obtain the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) (as discussed above in the context of the “random pure state”).

We also note that there is another way to generate an ensemble that can be used to perform the average: We can pick a fixed initial state |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0|\Psi_{0}\rangle, but consider an ensemble of states whose members consist of the time-series of states originating from the time-evolution of this fixed state by different amounts of time tm≡T0+m​δ​tsubscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑇0𝑚𝛿𝑡t_{m}\equiv T_{0}+m\ \delta t, where T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} is a large time ensuring that the initial state has “thermalized”, δ​t𝛿𝑡\delta t is some time-step (=Tabsent𝑇=T in the Floquet case), and m=1,2,…,M𝑚12…𝑀m=1,2,...,M, i.e.

|Ψ0​(tm)⟩=U^​(tm)​|Ψ0⟩,(m=1,…,M).ketsubscriptΨ0subscript𝑡𝑚^𝑈subscript𝑡𝑚ketsubscriptΨ0𝑚1…𝑀|\Psi_{0}(t_{m})\rangle={\hat{U}}(t_{m})|\Psi_{0}\rangle,\qquad(m=1,...,M). (13)

In this situation the time-average over the set of states (13) at times tmsubscript𝑡𝑚t_{m} then generates the ensemble-average of the spectral form factor. The resulting averaged spectral form factor is displayed in Fig. 4, and seen to exhibit the same universal linear “ramp” as that arising from averaging over the ensemble of initial states |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0|\Psi_{0}\rangle displayed in Fig.3.

II.3.2 Quantum Ising model

In this section we study the transverse field quantum Ising Hamiltonian with a longitudinal field. The Hamiltonian is

H^=∑iσ^iz​σ^i+1z+hx​∑iσ^ix+hz​∑iσ^iz.^𝐻subscript𝑖subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑧𝑖subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑧𝑖1subscriptℎ𝑥subscript𝑖subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑥𝑖subscriptℎ𝑧subscript𝑖subscriptsuperscript^𝜎𝑧𝑖\hat{H}=\sum_{i}\hat{\sigma}^{z}_{i}\hat{\sigma}^{z}_{i+1}+h_{x}\sum_{i}\hat{\sigma}^{x}_{i}+h_{z}\sum_{i}\hat{\sigma}^{z}_{i}~{}. (14)

The system parameters are (hx,hz)=(1.05,0.5)subscriptℎ𝑥subscriptℎ𝑧1.050.5(h_{x},h_{z})=(1.05,0.5).Bañuls et al. (2011) This model is far from integrable due to the large longitudinal field. The reduced density matrix of the initial direct product state will eventually thermalize under the time-evolution generated by the time-independent Hamiltonian (14), the total energy always being conserved. We choose the initial states to be random product states with Hamiltonian expectation values E𝐸E within a small energy interval E∈[−0.1,0.1]𝐸0.10.1E\in[-0.1,0.1] (close to the middle of the spectrum of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}), and study the spectral correlations and the emergence of a “ramp” in the spectrum of eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix at a sufficiently long time t=100𝑡100t=100, when the system is fully thermalized. The results are presented in Fig. 3. We see that the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle is indistinguishable from that computed for the “random pure state”, as well as from that computed for the Floquet model, for times τ𝜏\tau ranging from close to two orders of magnitude below the Heisenberg time scale all the way up to the plateau and it exhibits a linear “ramp” in that range of times τ𝜏\tau. On the other hand, there is some difference in the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)=subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏absentg_{c}(\tau)= [⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩−⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩]delimited-[]delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏[\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle-\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle] displayed in Fig. 3: The length of the “ramp” for the Ising model is shorter than that for “random pure state”, and that for the Floquet model, and shows an overshoot at early τ𝜏\tau. This suggests that for the Ising model, whose time-evolution is constrained by the energy conservation law, the subsystem is “less chaotic” in the sense that model-dependent features appear in the connected spectral form factor already at (small) times, here τ≈τ0=104≈10−2​τH𝜏subscript𝜏0superscript104superscript102subscript𝜏𝐻\tau\approx\tau_{0}=10^{4}\approx 10^{-2}\tau_{H}, see Fig. 3, reflecting deviations from universal spectral correlations for eigenvalues λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} at correspondingly large separations. We will discuss this issue in more detail in the next section.

III The development of chaos and thermalization in Floquet and Ising model

In this section, we study the development of quantum chaos in the many-body wave function. Starting (as before) with an initial product state |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0|\Psi_{0}\rangle, the time-evolved reduced density matrix ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) of the subsystem,

ρ^A​(t)=TrB​[U^​(t)​|Ψ0⟩​⟨Ψ0|​U^†​(t)],subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡subscriptTr𝐵delimited-[]^𝑈𝑡ketsubscriptΨ0brasubscriptΨ0superscript^𝑈†𝑡\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t)=\mbox{Tr}_{B}\left[{\hat{U}}(t)|\Psi_{0}\rangle\langle\Psi_{0}|{\hat{U}}^{{\dagger}}(t)\right], (15)

will eventually thermalize under the unitary time evolution operator U^​(t)^𝑈𝑡{\hat{U}}(t) of a generic non-integrable system, and its spectrum will in the process develop universal spectral correlations, manifested by a linear “ramp” in the corresponding spectral form factor. In this section we ask: At what times t𝑡t, under the quantum mechanical time evolution, does the “ramp” emerge, and how does it evolve in time t𝑡t until it reaches its final fully thermalized regime at long times? That is, we will be studying the development of chaos in the density matrix. To answer these questions, we will study the spectral form factor at different times t𝑡t before ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) has fully thermalized.

III.1 Floquet System

We first study the Floquet system defined in (11) and (12).Kim et al. (2014); D’Alessio and Rigol (2014); Lazarides et al. (2014); Ponte et al. (2015); Zhang et al. (2015) As shown in the inset of Fig. 5, when the subsystem size is LA=9subscript𝐿𝐴9L_{A}=9 (total system size L=20𝐿20L=20), the EE grows linearly with time t=n​T𝑡𝑛𝑇t=nT for time-steps n≤10𝑛10n\leq 10, and then quickly saturates exponentially in the time-step n𝑛n to the Page value. As is clearly seen from the inset of Fig. 5, at time-step n=30𝑛30n=30 the deviation of the EE from its Page value is negligible.

When we consider the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle for the same density matrix ρ^A​(t=n​T)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡𝑛𝑇{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT), the “ramp” starts to emerge at time-step n=11𝑛11n=11: In Fig. 5, we can clearly observe that as the time-step n𝑛n increases beyond n=11𝑛11n=11, the dip in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) becomes much deeper, and at the same time the “ramp” is getting longer. At time-step n=15𝑛15n=15, the length of the “ramp” in g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle is already very close to that observed at time-step n=30𝑛30n=30. In Fig. 5 we plot the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)=subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏absentg_{c}(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩−⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle-\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle, which is seen to exhibit a “ramp” whose length continues to increase beyond time-step n=15𝑛15n=15 until the fully thermalized regime at time-step n=30𝑛30n=30 is reached. These plots also show an overshoot at the low-τ𝜏\tau end of the “ramp” in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau), which is however suppressed as the time-step n𝑛n increases further, and at n=30𝑛30n=30 the overshoot has basically disappeared (and gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau) is the same as that for the “random pure state” - compare Fig. 3 (b)), indicating that at this time-step chaos has fully developed in the subsystem. All these time scales depend on the length LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A} of the subsystem and become smaller as the subsystem size LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A} is decreased.

We note that we have obtained the above results upon computing the spectral form factor by using in (3) or (7) all the eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix ρ^A​(t=n​T)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡𝑛𝑇{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT). Actually, in order to gain additional insight, it is useful to limit the eigenvalues used to compute the spectral form factor in (3) or (7) to a subset lying in a window around a fixed eigenvalue, and to compute the spectral form factor by only using the eigenvalues of the density matrix in this window. This procedure can then detect “local universal spectral correlations” characterizing the correlations amongst the eigenvalues in this window. In Fig. 6, we present results for the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle for a window of 10 consecutive eigenvalues at the top of spectrum999 We choose here the 10 largest eigenvalues, of a total of approx. NA=500subscript𝑁𝐴500N_{A}=500 levels of ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}. in ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}. We notice the appearance of a linear “ramp” as early as at time-step n=5𝑛5n=5. As we move the window of eigenvalues away from the top to the bottom of the spectrum of the density matrix101010We choose here the 10 smallest eigenvalues, of a total of approx. NA=500subscript𝑁𝐴500N_{A}=500 levels of ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}. , we find that the linear “ramp” develops only at later time-steps - here at n=11𝑛11n=11 (Fig. 6). This result demonstrates that in the Floquet model, as time t𝑡t evolves, the universal spectral correlations first emerge at the top of spectrum of ρ^A​(t=n​T)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡𝑛𝑇{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT) and subsequently spread over the entire spectrum at later times t𝑡t. This behavior, i.e. the fact that not the entire spectrum of the density matrix develops the spectral correlations uniformly in time t𝑡t, is also responsible for the shallowness of the dip that appears, when the time-step n𝑛n is between 11 and 15, in the plot in Fig. 5 of the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle which uses the entire spectrum as input.

Finally, we would like to discuss the connection between the linear growth of the EE and the development of universal spectral correlations. When we look at the magnitudes of the eigenvalues of ρA​(t)subscript𝜌𝐴𝑡\rho_{A}(t) at early times, we find that there are only a few of them which are appreciably different from zero; and it is them that exhibit the spectral correlations and are also responsible for the observed value of the EE. Actually, they also give rise to the volume law in the EE for smaller subsystem sizes. As time evolves, more and more eigenvalues become appreciably different from zero. They develop spectral correlations and lead to the linear growth of the EE. This is in contrast with an integrable system, where the linear growth of the EE is due to the ballistic propagation of quasiparticlesCalabrese and Cardy (2007) and there are no spectral correlations between the eigenvalues and hence there is no “ramp” in the spectral form factor.111111See the last paragraph before Sec. III.3 and Fig. 9. In Sec. III.3 we will show an example of such a phenomenon within a Floquet system.

III.2 Ising Model

In this section we investigate the development of chaos in a quantum Ising model, where the thermalization process is slower due to the presence of the energy conservation law.

High energy states: For an ensemble of initial random direct product states |Ψ0⟩ketsubscriptΨ0|\Psi_{0}\rangle with Hamiltonian expectation value in the small energy interval E∈[−0.1,0.1]𝐸0.10.1E\in[-0.1,0.1] (i.e. E=⟨Ψ0|H^|Ψ0⟩𝐸quantum-operator-productsubscriptΨ0^𝐻subscriptΨ0E=\langle\Psi_{0}|{\hat{H}}|\Psi_{0}\rangle in the middle of the spectrum of the Ising Hamiltonian H^^𝐻{\hat{H}} in (14)), the EE grows linearly with time until t≈7𝑡7t\approx 7 and then saturates exponentially to the final volume law at longer times around t=100𝑡100t=100 [see inset in Fig. 7(b)]. Since this initial state has energy E𝐸E close to zero (middle of the spectrum of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}), the effective temperature is high and the saturation value of the EE is only slightly smaller than the Page value. In particular, when LA=9subscript𝐿𝐴9L_{A}=9 (total system size L=20𝐿20L=20), the difference between the two values of the EE is seen to be around 0.0045, which is less than 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the EE of the Page state.

In Fig. 7, we present results for the spectral form factors g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle and gc​(τ)=subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏absentg_{c}(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩−⟨Z​(τ)⟩​⟨Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle-\langle Z(\tau)\rangle\langle Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle at different times t𝑡t. In Fig. 7, the “ramp” in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) starts to emerge at around t=9𝑡9t=9. As t𝑡t increases further, the dip becomes deeper and shifts to earlier times. At t=15𝑡15t=15, a linear “ramp” has fully developed and remains almost unchanged until the system is fully thermalized at t=100𝑡100t=100. In Fig. 7 we plot the connected spectral form factor gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau), which is seen to exhibit a “ramp” that continues to grow further in length, even beyond time t=15𝑡15t=15. However, in contrast to the Floquet model, the overshoot appearing at the low-τ𝜏\tau end of the “ramp” cannot be fully suppressed and is always present even after a very long time evolution ( - compare also Fig. 3(b)). This indicates that the energy conservation law makes the Ising model “less chaotic” than the Floquet model, in the sense that universal spectral correlations do not extend to pairs of eigenvalues λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} as far separated as in the Floquet model. We have also computed the spectral form factor using only a subset of eigenvalues of ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) in a window around an eigenvalue at the top, in the middle and at the bottom of its spectrum and we find similar behavior as in the Floquet model: Universal spectral correlations first emerge at the top of the spectrum and then spread over the rest of spectrum.

Lower energy states: Since for the Ising model energy is conserved, we can also study the spectral correlations of ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) which arise upon time evolution starting from an initial state with a lower energy E𝐸E (= Hamiltonian expectation value =⟨ψ0|H^|ψ0⟩absentquantum-operator-productsubscript𝜓0^𝐻subscript𝜓0=\langle\psi_{0}|{\hat{H}}|\psi_{0}\rangle) corresponding to properties of the quantum Ising Hamiltonian (14) at relatively low temperatures. (Though, E𝐸E is separated from the ground state by many levels. The spectrum of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}} has support in an interval which is approximately [−26,+33]2633[-26,+33].) In particular, we consider an initial direct product state close to the Neel state with an energy in the narrow interval E∈[−14.1,−13.9]𝐸14.113.9E\in[-14.1,-13.9] rather than the random product state in the middle of the spectrum of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}, which has high excitation energy E𝐸E, considered above. Furthermore, we introduce some randomness into this ensemble of initial states so that we can perform a disorder (ensemble) average over them. Under the unitary time evolution evolution, the EE is found to initially grow linearly with time t𝑡t, and to saturate as expected to a smaller volume law after long time evolution as compared to the case of a random initial state with energy E𝐸E in the middle of the spectrum of H^^𝐻{\hat{H}}. For LA=9subscript𝐿𝐴9L_{A}=9 (total system size L=20𝐿20L=20), we start to observe a dip in the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle at times around t=9𝑡9t=9. As before, we also compute the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​Z∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍superscript𝑍\langle ZZ^{*}\rangle by only using a subset of eigenvalues of ρ^A​(t)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t) locally in a window around a fixed eigenvalue of the density matrix. For a window of 10 consecutive eigenvalues close to the top of the spectrum of the density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} we find, similar to the Floquet model, a “ramp” already at an early time t=4𝑡4t=4 which becomes linear at t=6𝑡6t=6 (Fig. 8). On the other hand, as we move the window of 10 consecutive eigenvalues close to the bottom of the spectrum of the density matrix (Fig. 8), the spectral correlations emerge only at later times t𝑡t as compared to the case where the window is at the top of the spectrum. This is analgous to what was observed in the Floquet case.

Finally, we turn off the longitudinal field hzsubscriptℎ𝑧h_{z} in the quantum Ising Hamiltonian (14), so that the model becomes integrable. An initial random direct product state equilibrates after the quantum quench to a thermal state described by the generalized Gibbs ensemble (GGE) with an extensive number of conserved quantities.Rigol et al. (2007, 2006); Calabrese and Cardy (2007) As shown in Fig. 9, we do not observe any “ramp” in the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle, indicating the absence of chaos reflected in the absence of universal spectral correlations in the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}.

III.3 Floquet system with prethermal regime

As discussed before, for a generic Floquet system the reduced density matrix of a general short-range entangled initial state will reach a steady state at infinite temperature after a sufficiently long time evolution, since energy is not conserved.Kim et al. (2014); D’Alessio and Rigol (2014); Ponte et al. (2015); D’Alessio and Polkovnikov (2013) How thermal equilibrium and chaos emerge in the wavefunction is model-dependent. Recently, it has been shown that a rapidly driven system may exhibit an intermediate prethermal regime of long duration in which the system reaches a thermal equilibrium state governed by an approximate time-independent Hamiltonian with the effective temperature set by the initial energy.Mori et al. (2016); Abanin et al. (2015, 2017); Else et al. (2017); Machado et al. (2017) This regime can have an exponentially long lifetime (in units of inverse frequency, and other parameters of the system). We note that a prethermalized regime in a system with a time-independent (as opposed to Floquet) Hamiltonian has also been considered recently in the context of non-integrable perturbations of integrable many-body systems121212See e.g. Ref. Bertini et al., 2016 and references therein., but we do not discuss these situations here.

In this section, we are going to explore a Floquet model that exhibits such prethermalization to a thermal state which is close to that of a nearly-integrable system. The Floquet operator that we use to achieve such a prethermalized regime takes the following form,

U^F=exp⁡[−i​t0​H^1]​exp⁡[−i​t0​H^2],subscript^𝑈𝐹𝑖subscript𝑡0subscript^𝐻1𝑖subscript𝑡0subscript^𝐻2\displaystyle\hat{U}_{F}=\exp[-it_{0}\hat{H}_{1}]\exp\left[-it_{0}\hat{H}_{2}\right]~{}, (16)

where

H^1=−∑j=1L−1σ^jz​σ^j+1z−hx​∑j=1Lσ^jxsubscript^𝐻1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿1superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗𝑧superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗1𝑧subscriptℎ𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗𝑥\displaystyle\hat{H}_{1}=-\sum_{j=1}^{L-1}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{z}\hat{\sigma}_{j+1}^{z}-h_{x}\sum_{j=1}^{L}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{x}
H^2=−hy​∑j=1Lσ^jy.subscript^𝐻2subscriptℎ𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿superscriptsubscript^𝜎𝑗𝑦\displaystyle\hat{H}_{2}=-h_{y}\sum_{j=1}^{L}\hat{\sigma}_{j}^{y}~{}. (17)

This model is a one-dimensional periodically driven system with period T=2​t0𝑇2subscript𝑡0T=2t_{0}. In the numerical calculations, we choose open boundary conditions and system parameters (hx,hy)=(1,1)subscriptℎ𝑥subscriptℎ𝑦11(h_{x},h_{y})=(1,1). The period T=0.2𝑇0.2T=0.2 is chosen to be very small in order to realize a long prethermal regime.

Since the period T𝑇T is very small, it takes a large number of time-steps for the Floquet system to relax to its ultimate, fully thermalized (chaotic) state. The previous method used above for rapidly thermalizing Floquet systems that simply amounted to applying the time-evolution operator many times to an initial state, which did not require diagonalizing the Floquet operator, is no longer useful here due to the large number of required time-steps. Here we will instead consider a smaller system size with L=14𝐿14L=14 so that we can diagonalize the Floquet operator explicitly and study the long time dynamics by applying that operator for any length of time to the initial state. We start with a random direct product state and evolve it under the Floquet operator. The result for the time evolution of the EE is shown in Fig. 10, where we clearly observe a long intermediate plateau which corresponds to the prethermalized regime. We further have computed the spectral form factor g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle in this (prethermalized) regime and we do not observe any dip or “ramp”, demonstrating that the eigenvalues of the reduced density matrix ρ^A​(t=n​T)subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑡𝑛𝑇{\hat{\rho}}_{A}(t=nT) do not exhibit any universal spectral correlations in this regime. The lack of the spectral correlations shows that chaos is absent in this regime, and we expect that it is described by a Generalized Gibbs Ensemble (GGE). On the other hand, chaos starts to appear at yet longer times where the EE increases further and eventually relaxes to the Page value; at those longer times, a small “ramp” is seen to develop in the spectral form factor depicted in Fig. 11 (b). A more pronounced linear “ramp” can be observed (see Fig. 11) once the state reaches full thermalization at still larger time-steps n𝑛n.

Therefore, in the present Floquet model, we can separate the long time evolution into four stages (see Fig.s 10 and 11): (1) a regime of linear growth of the EE, which also appears in all of the previous models (see inset of Fig. 10), (2) the prethermal regime described by GGE and absence of chaos, which is reflected by a plateau in the time-evolution of the EE, (3) the regime of development of chaos where universal spectral correlations start to develop at the top of the spectrum of the density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}, and (4) the fully thermalized regime, where the initial state has time-evolved into a state whose reduced density matrix exhibits a spectrum indistinguishable from that of the density matrix of a featureless “random pure state”.

IV Analytical calculations for the “random pure state”

IV.1 Random pure state and Wishart-Laguerre ensemble

In this subsection we briefly review the connection between the reduced density matrix of the “random pure state” (Page state) and the Wishart random matrix ensemble. First, we decompose the total Hilbert space into a tensor product of the Hilbert spaces of the two subsystems A𝐴A and B𝐵B with dimensions NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} and NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B}, respectively (assuming NA≤NBsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N_{A}\leq N_{B} without loss of generality), and write the “random pure state” defined in (5) in a direct (tensor) product basis

|Ψ⟩=∑i=1NA∑J=1NBXi​J​|ΨAi⟩⊗|ΨBJ⟩ketΨsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐽1subscript𝑁𝐵tensor-productsubscript𝑋𝑖𝐽ketsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝐴𝑖ketsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝐵𝐽\displaystyle|\Psi\rangle=\sum_{i=1}^{N_{A}}\sum_{J=1}^{N_{B}}X_{iJ}\ |\Psi_{A}^{i}\rangle\otimes|\Psi_{B}^{J}\rangle (18)

where the coefficients Xi​Jsubscript𝑋𝑖𝐽X_{iJ} are complex Gaussian random variables, and form a rectangular NA×NBsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N_{A}\times N_{B} random matrix X𝑋X subject to the normalization constraint Tr​(X​X†)=1Tr𝑋superscript𝑋†1\mbox{Tr}(XX^{{\dagger}})=1. After tracing out subsystem B, we obtain from this wavefunction the reduced density matrix ρ^A=X​X†subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑋superscript𝑋†{\hat{\rho}}_{A}=XX^{{\dagger}} for subsystem A, which is a NA×NAsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}\times N_{A} square matrix.

In order to make contact with the Wishart-Laguerre random matrix ensemble, we consider a (unconstrained) NA×NBsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N_{A}\times N_{B} complex random matrix Y={Yi​J}𝑌subscript𝑌𝑖𝐽Y=\{Y_{iJ}\} whose statistically independent complex matrix elements are drawn from a Gaussian probability distribution

P​({Yi​J})=𝒩−1​exp⁡{−β2​NB​Tr​(Y​Y†)}.𝑃subscript𝑌𝑖𝐽superscript𝒩1𝛽2subscript𝑁𝐵Tr𝑌superscript𝑌†\displaystyle P(\{Y_{iJ}\})={\cal N}^{-1}\exp\{-{\beta\over 2}\ N_{B}\mbox{Tr}(YY^{\dagger})\}. (19)

The NA×NAsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}\times N_{A} matrix W≡Y​Y†𝑊𝑌superscript𝑌†W\equiv YY^{\dagger} is then a random matrix belonging to what is known as the β=2𝛽2\beta=2 (“GUE-type”) Wishart random matrix ensemble. Consequently, the density matrix for the “random pure state”, discussed above, can be expressed in terms of the Wishart random matrix as follows

ρ^A≡Y​Y†Tr​(Y​Y†).subscript^𝜌𝐴𝑌superscript𝑌†Tr𝑌superscript𝑌†\displaystyle{\hat{\rho}}_{A}\equiv{YY^{\dagger}\over\mbox{Tr}(YY^{\dagger})}. (20)

We finally note that the denominator on the right hand side of (20) has expectation value

⟨Tr​(Y​Y†)⟩=∑i=1NA∑J=1NB⟨|Yi​J|2⟩=(NA​NB)NB=NA.delimited-⟨⟩Tr𝑌superscript𝑌†superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐽1subscript𝑁𝐵delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖𝐽2subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵subscript𝑁𝐵subscript𝑁𝐴\displaystyle\langle\mbox{Tr}(YY^{\dagger})\rangle=\sum_{i=1}^{N_{A}}\sum_{J=1}^{N_{B}}\ \langle|Y_{iJ}|^{2}\rangle={(N_{A}N_{B})\over N_{B}}=N_{A}. (21)

Thus, in the limit where both NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} and NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} tend to infinity while the ratio α≡NA/NB𝛼subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵\alpha\equiv N_{A}/N_{B} remains fixed, the relative fluctuations f𝑓f of the random variable Tr​(Y​Y†)=Tr𝑌superscript𝑌†absent\mbox{Tr}(YY^{\dagger})= NA​(1+f)subscript𝑁𝐴1𝑓N_{A}(1+f) about its mean NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} vanish, and we can replace

Tr​(Y​Y†)→NA.→Tr𝑌superscript𝑌†subscript𝑁𝐴\displaystyle\mbox{Tr}(YY^{\dagger})\to N_{A}. (22)

Owing to (20) the eigenvalues λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} are thus related in the limit of large NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} and NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} to the eigenvalues μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} of the Wishart matrix W𝑊W via

λi=μiNA.subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝑁𝐴\displaystyle\lambda_{i}={\mu_{i}\over N_{A}}. (23)

Clearly, the above-described relationship immediately extends to the other two universality classes of GOE (β=1𝛽1\beta=1) and GSE (β=4𝛽4\beta=4) “random pure state”s and Wishart random matrix ensembles.

IV.2 Eigenvalue statistics of the Wishart-Laguerre ensemble

Here we first briefly review some important results for the Wishart-Laguerre random matrix ensemble.Forrester (2010) For more details, see Appendix B.

In general, for a Wishart matrix W=Y​Y†𝑊𝑌superscript𝑌†W=YY^{{\dagger}} with Y𝑌Y being a NA×NBsubscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N_{A}\times N_{B} matrix with real (β=1)𝛽1(\beta=1), complex (β=2)𝛽2(\beta=2) or quaternion (β=4)𝛽4(\beta=4) Gaussian entries drawn from the joint distribution as in (19), the joint probability probability distribution for the NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} eigenvalues μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i} of W𝑊W is known to beForrester (2010)

wherewhere\displaystyle{\rm where}
E​[{μi}]=12​∑iN[V​(μi)−12​log⁡|μi−μj|],μi>0,formulae-sequence𝐸delimited-[]subscript𝜇𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑁delimited-[]𝑉subscript𝜇𝑖12subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖0\displaystyle\qquad\qquad E[\{\mu_{i}\}]=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i}^{N}\left[V(\mu_{i})-\frac{1}{2}\log|\mu_{i}-\mu_{j}|\right],\quad\mu_{i}>0,

and V​(μ)=(μ−κ​log⁡μ)𝑉𝜇𝜇𝜅𝜇V(\mu)=(\mu-\kappa\log\mu) with κ=(1+NB−NA)−2/β𝜅1subscript𝑁𝐵subscript𝑁𝐴2𝛽\kappa=(1+N_{B}-N_{A})-2/\beta;   𝒩~−1superscript~𝒩1{\cal{\tilde{N}}}^{-1} is a normalization factor. IV.3 Spectral form factor for the reduced density matrix from Wishart Random Matrix Theory

For any random matrix ensemble with the joint probability density described by (24), the level-level correlation function (“pair correlation function”) is universal and only dependsNagao and Wadati (1992); Brézin and Zee (1993) on the symmetry type, although the spectral density depends on the explicit form of the potential V​(μi)𝑉subscript𝜇𝑖V(\mu_{i}) defined in (24). Specifically, the connected correlation function of the spectral density ν^​(λ)^𝜈𝜆{\hat{\nu}}(\lambda), defined in (28), takes for Dyson index β=2𝛽2\beta=2 (“GUE-type” class) in the large NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} limit the following universal form which can be expressed in terms of the celebrated so-called sine-kernelFox and Kahn (1964); Nagao and Wadati (1992); Brézin and Zee (1993),

⟨ν^​(λ)​ν^​(λ′)⟩−⟨ν^​(λ)⟩​⟨ν^​(λ′)⟩=⟨ν^​(E)⟩​δ​(ω)−⟨ν^​(λ)⟩​⟨ν^​(λ′)⟩​sin2⁡[π​⟨ν^​(E)⟩​ω][π​⟨ν^​(E)⟩​ω]2,delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈𝜆^𝜈superscript𝜆′delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈𝜆delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈superscript𝜆′delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈𝐸𝛿𝜔delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈𝜆delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈superscript𝜆′superscript2𝜋delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈𝐸𝜔superscriptdelimited-[]𝜋delimited-⟨⟩^𝜈𝐸𝜔2\displaystyle\langle{\hat{\nu}}(\lambda){\hat{\nu}}(\lambda^{\prime})\rangle-\langle{\hat{\nu}}(\lambda)\rangle\ \langle{\hat{\nu}}(\lambda^{\prime})\rangle=\langle{\hat{\nu}}(E)\rangle\ \delta(\omega)-\langle{\hat{\nu}}(\lambda)\rangle\ \langle{\hat{\nu}}(\lambda^{\prime})\rangle\ \frac{\sin^{2}[\pi\langle{\hat{\nu}}(E)\rangle\omega]}{[\pi\langle{\hat{\nu}}(E)\rangle\omega]^{2}}, (36)

where

ω=λ−λ′,E=(λ+λ′)/2.formulae-sequence𝜔𝜆superscript𝜆′𝐸𝜆superscript𝜆′2\displaystyle\omega=\lambda-\lambda^{\prime},\qquad E=(\lambda+\lambda^{\prime})/2. (37)

we obtain (for more details see Appendix B.3)
