where we recall that N=NA​NB𝑁subscript𝑁𝐴subscript𝑁𝐵N=N_{A}N_{B}. The regime of linear growth with τ𝜏\tau is universal and reflects the universal spectral correlations present in the spectrum, which are represented by the sine-kernel on the right hand side of (36). Note also that the prefactor of the linear growth term in (41) is independent of subsystem size NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}. This is the origin of the fact that the linear “ramps” appearing for different subsystem sizes NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} all lie on top of each other - see e.g. Fig 2. The spectral form factors of the entanglement Hamiltonian, discussed in Appendix A and depicted in Fig. 12 do not show this feature, but are instead shifted with respect to each other by a NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}-dependent constant (on a log-log plot), reflecting a NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}-dependent coefficient of the term linear in τ𝜏\tau.

In view of (33),(35),(38),(41), the disconnected part in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) hides the early-time τ𝜏\tau part of the universal linear “ramp” (41) appearing in gc​(τ)subscript𝑔𝑐𝜏g_{c}(\tau). This effect gives rise to the “dip” (minimum) in g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau), and allows one to estimate the “dip-time” τdsubscript𝜏𝑑\tau_{d} as follows: Equating |⟨Z​(τ)⟩|2superscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏2|\langle Z(\tau)\rangle|^{2} and the “ramp” in (41) gives the dip time in ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle. Based on this logic, we expect the dip time τdsubscript𝜏𝑑\tau_{d} to be around (NA​N)1/2superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐴𝑁12(N_{A}N)^{1/2} when α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, which is consistent with the numerical results. On the other hand, when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, this logic yields τd∼NA2similar-tosubscript𝜏𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐴2\tau_{d}\sim N_{A}^{2}. However this is a time scale of the order of the plateau time τp=subscript𝜏𝑝absent\tau_{p}= τHsubscript𝜏𝐻\tau_{H}, and therefore we cannot observe the “ramp” in g​(τ)=𝑔𝜏absentg(\tau)= ⟨Z​(τ)​Z∗​(τ)⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑍𝜏superscript𝑍𝜏\langle Z(\tau)Z^{*}(\tau)\rangle when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, consistent with our numerical findings reported above.

V Discussion and Conclusion

In conclusion, we have explored the presence of universal spectral correlations in the spectrum of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of a many-body wavefunction and used the presence of these correlations to define quantum chaos at the level of a single many-body wavefunction. To detect these spectral correlations, we constructed the spectral form factor g​(τ)𝑔𝜏g(\tau) for ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} and identified the presence of a “ramp” as a hallmark of the spectral correlations. We explicitly considered three wavefunctions: the “random pure state”, a typical state of a Floquet spin model, and of a quantum Ising model in both transverse and longitudinal fields, both in one spatial dimenstion. In all three cases, we numerically found the presence of the universal linear “ramp” in the spectral form factor. For the “random pure state”, we also analytically computed the spectral form factor by using Wishart random matrix theory and found agreement with our numerical results.

Moreover, we discussed how universal spectral correlations develop in a quantum quench problem from an initial product state lacking chaos. We found that the spectral correlations first emerge at the top of spectrum of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A}, and then spread over the entire spectrum at later times. We verified this statement numerically in both, the Floquet and quantum Ising models. Finally we studied a rapidly driven Floquet system which posseses a long prethermalized regime exhibiting an “EE plateau”, on which the system can be well approximated by a GGE. For times when the system is on that EE plateau, we don’t observe any “ramp” in the spectral form factor, which is consistent with the absence of chaos in the GGE. We found that universal spectral correlations (and a “ramp”) in the density matrix develop only when the wavefunction starts to relax to the fully thermalized regime at late times.

Appendix A Spectral Form Factor of the Entanglement Hamiltonian

Numerical results for the spectral form factor of the entanglement Hamiltonian H^Esubscript^𝐻𝐸{\hat{H}}_{E} of the “random pure state” are displayed in Fig. 12, and are to be compared with the spectral form factor of the reduced density matrix ρ^Asubscript^𝜌𝐴{\hat{\rho}}_{A} of the same system, depicted in Fig. 2. We see that both spectral form factors exhibit a linear “ramp” (unit slope on a the log-log plot), which is the hallmark of universal spectral correlations. The form factors of the entanglement Hamiltonian are shifted by a NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}-dependent constant on the log-log plot, which reflects a NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A}-dependent prefactor of the linear τ𝜏\tau-dependence.

Recall that entanglement Hamiltonian and density matrix are related as in (4), and that, as mentioned in the sentence below (4), the spectral form factor of the former is obtained from that of the latter by letting λi→−ln⁡λi→subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}\to-\ln\lambda_{i}, where λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} denotes the eigenvalues of the reduced density matix.
